item.title: Facebook under fire over secret teen research
item.description: It had evidence Instagram was a harmful place for young people - but failed to share its findings.

item.title: Microsoft's passwordless plans lets users switch to app-based login
item.description: Microsoft says users can delete all passwords from their accounts and use a different login system.

item.title: TikTok faces privacy investigations by EU watchdog
item.description: The Irish regulator says it is looking at how TikTok handles children's data - and where it goes.

item.title: Three ex-US intelligence officers admit hacking for UAE
item.description: The three men allegedly helped a UAE-based firm break into computers and phones around the world.

item.title: Firms fined over 'frustrating' nuisance messages
item.description: We Buy Any Car, Saga and Sports Direct are fined for sending millions of nuisance messages.

item.title: Apple iPhone 13 brings portrait mode for video
item.description: The portrait-mode style video setting can pull focus on its subjects automatically.

item.title: Deathloop reviews: 'Ingenious' shooter is a contender for game of the year
item.description: The action thriller, which takes place in a time loop, delights critics as it debuts on Playstation 5.

item.title: Mental health: TikTok rolls out support to combat suicide searches
item.description: The move comes as Instagram is facing fresh scrutiny over its impact on young people's wellbeing.

item.title: Canva: Australian online design platform valued at $40bn
item.description: The online design platform has become one of the most valuable private firms in the world.

item.title: Israel-Palestinian Facebook posts need 'bias' review
item.description: One of the recommendations from the Facebook Oversight Board after ruling on one such post.

item.title: 'Massive' transatlantic data cable landed on beach in Bude
item.description: The new 7,000km-long internet cable connecting the UK and US has been brought ashore in Cornwall.

item.title: Apple rushes to block 'zero-click' iPhone spyware
item.description: The flaw allows hackers to access devices even if users do not click on a link or file.

item.title: Why Icelandâ€™s volcanoes may aid future Mars exploration
item.description: Scientists are using the country to test drone tech that could one day explore the planet's terrain.

item.title: The world's most powerful magnetic field and other news
item.description: BBC Click's LJ Rich looks at some of the week's best technology stories.

item.title: Is this the era of a more shopping focused social media?
item.description: Virtual retail is changing and becoming more embedded in our day to day online activities.

item.title: Esports: Why are there so few professional women gamers?
item.description: There are no female players in the top 300 earners in esports, according to research shared with BBC News.

item.title: Meet Digit, the workplace robot, and other news
item.description: BBC Click's Marc Cieslak looks at the best of the week's technology news.

item.title: Why even giant ships can't solve the shipping crisis
item.description: A shortage of vessels is hampering global trade and may lead to empty shelves before Christmas.

item.title: Jesse Lingard takes control of a Rainbow Six Siege esports team
item.description: The footballer believes his experiences on the pitch will translate to the online world.

item.title: The pressures - and rewards - of being an influencer
item.description: Running your own popular YouTube channel can be lucrative, but it comes with downsides.

item.title: Could a reboot make social media a nicer place?
item.description: A Harvard University project will explore whether social media can be de-toxed

item.title: The Kenyans who are helping the world to cheat
item.description: Some Kenyans try to escape poverty by helping foreign students to fake their academic work.

item.title: The models that turned Instagram into their DIY catwalk
item.description: New York Fashion Week marks a tentative return - but how did supermodels keep working through Covid?

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.

item.title: How to back up your data and keep it safe
item.description: Experts recommend using three drives to back up your data and using cloud-based services.
